sen.j: 磯田多佳（いそだ・たか 本名たか 1879年 - 1945年）は、祇園甲部の芸妓で京都市東山区祇園新橋に営業していたお茶屋『大友（だいとも）』の女将。
sen.e: Taka ISODA (her real name was Taka, from 1879 to 1945) was Geisya in Gion Kobu, and she was Okami (mistress) of "Daitomo", a tea shop which was operated in Gion-Shinbashi, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 多佳は6歳で井上八千代に入門。
sen.e: Taka became a disciple of Yachiyo INOUE at the age of six.

sen.j: そこで芸を磨き、10代で芸妓となる。
sen.e: Se brushed up her entertainment skill in INOUE's place, and became Geisya in her 10's.

sen.j: 23歳で母の家業を継ぎ、夏目漱石をはじめ谷崎潤一郎、吉井勇など多くの文学者との交流し、『文学芸妓』と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: She took over her mother's business at the age of 23, and interacted with many literature scholars including Soseki NATSUME, Junichiro TANIZAKI, Isamu YOSHII; that was why she came to be called as "Literature geisya."

sen.j: 当時白川の両岸には数軒の御茶屋が立ち並び、その中に『大友』が含まれていて吉井勇の歌にも書かれている。
sen.e: The both banks of Shira-kawa River were lined with some tea shops including "Otomo", which was written in Isamu YOSHII's poem.

sen.j: しかし、戦局が悪化し多くのお茶屋が廃業を余儀なくされた。
sen.e: As the war became worse, many tea shops were forced to be closed.

sen.j: 空襲に伴う災害を防ぐため疎開が行われ、多佳が守っていたお茶屋が撤去され、彼女は悲しみにくれた。
sen.e: Evacuation was carried out to minimize disasters caused by air attacks, and she was grieved when her tea shop which she had been protecting was cleared.
